marketNews.title: BYD Officially Enters Indonesia Next Week
marketNews.content: Build Your Dream (BYD), the Chinese electric vehicle manufacturer, announced that it will launch its products in Indonesia on 18 January 2024. CNN Indonesia reported that BYD will release three electric car models in Indonesia: Dolphin, Atto 3, and Seal. Head of Marketing PT BYD Motor Indonesia, Luther Panjaitan, told Tempo that the Seal and Atto 3 models have already arrived in Indonesia. He also said that both models are ready to be marketed in Indonesia in the first half of 2024, although pricing details have not been announced. Before entering Indonesia, the Dolphin, Seal, and Atto 3 models were already sold in neighboring countries such as Thailand and Malaysia. Price ranges: Thailand (assuming 1 baht = 444 rupiah): Dolphin 311-382 million rupiah; Atto 3 488-533 million rupiah; Seal 578-711 million rupiah. Malaysia (assuming 1 ringgit = 3.344 rupiah): Dolphin 335-420 million rupiah; Atto 3 501-561 million rupiah. The BYD launch announcement comes less than a month after the issuance of Presidential Regulation No. 79 of 2023, which details incentives for imported CBU electric cars, including import duty exemption and VAT/PPnBM exemption. Previously, since 2018 BYD has been a supplier for Transjakarta electric buses and Blue Bird electric taxis (BIRD). Key Takeaway: Assuming Indonesian selling prices are similar to those in Thailand and Malaysia, BYD products could be more attractive to Indonesian electric car consumers because they offer higher value-for-money. In terms of pricing, BYD products would be positioned between the Wuling Air EV (250-300 million rupiah) and the Hyundai Ioniq 5 (750-900 million rupiah). In November 2023, Wuling EV and Hyundai Ioniq accounted for 40.7% and 37.9% of total electric vehicle sales respectively. Moreover, the presence of well-priced products could accelerate electric vehicle penetration in Indonesia. In November 2023, electric vehicle sales reached 2.25% of total car sales, up from 0.32% in January 2023.

marketNews.title: KPIG & BMTR Absorb 24.05% of BABP Shares Worth IDR 802 Billion
marketNews.content:
BABP: MNC Land (KPIG) and Global Mediacom (BMTR) each absorbed 7.48 billion and 3.21 billion shares of Bank MNC Internasional at a price of 75 rupiah per share on 4 January 2024. The total transaction values were 561 billion rupiah for KPIG and 241 billion rupiah for BMTR. After this transaction, the holdings of KPIG and BMTR in BABP increased from zero to 16.82% and 7.23% respectively. This transaction is part of a rights issue worth 1.01 trillion rupiah that BABP conducted in December 2023.

SMDR: The President Director of Samudera Indonesia, Bani M. Mulia, stated that the company has budgeted a capital expenditure of about 280 million US dollars for 2024. The funds will be used for the addition of 12 new vessels and a new port project. The new vessels include six container ships, two gas tankers, two tugboats, and two barges. The capex will be financed from internal cash, sukuk issuance, and bank loan facilities.

TPMA: The Director of Trans Power Marine, Rudy Sutiono, said that the company is allocating 20 million US dollars this year to purchase two tugboats, four barges, and one floating crane. Previously, TPMA operated 40 tugboats, 35 barges, and three floating cranes.

MIDI: Midi Utama Indonesia injected 70 billion rupiah of capital into its subsidiary PT Lancar Wiguna Sejahtera (LWS) through a new share subscription. LWS operates Lawson stores in Indonesia. Previously, MIDI planned to open 250 Lawson stores in 2024, with 200 of them using a store-in-store format.

Bank Indonesia announced that the Consumer Confidence Index for December 2023 rose to 123.8, compared with 123.6 in November 2023.

The Ministry of Public Works and Housing is reviewing a 35-year mortgage scheme adopted from Japan, which has been successful there. The Chief Economist of Bank Tabungan Negara (BBTN), Winang Budoyo, proposed a tiered interest-rate scheme with gradual increases over a ten-year period.

The Ministry of Industry reduced the electric motor subsidy quota for 2024 from 600,000 units to 50,000 units. The reduction is due to low sales of electric motorcycles in 2023, which reached only 11,532 units as of 26 December 2023, representing 5.76% of the FY23 target of 200,000 units.

Brent crude oil prices fell 3.26% on Monday (8 January), driven by a $2 per barrel price cut for Arab Light crude sold to Asian customers and an OPEC production increase of 70,000 barrels per month in December 2023. On Tuesday (9 January), Brent prices were stable, gaining 0.75% intraday, following continued geopolitical tension in the Middle East.
